comments.commentBody: Hedge Funds, and vultures like Ichan, use corporations like poker chips. Actual manufacturing is of little interest to them. Thus goes American business. In the case of HP, no amount of spinning will help if they continue the corporate culture created by Carlton Fiorina, that produced substandard products, and treated customers like dirt.

Well I was born in 1941 and remember listening to a live radio pickup from Sing Sing reporting the moment of execution. I also grew up in a largely communist neighborhood in Brooklyn (the upstairs neighbor was known as "Freda the Red").

Any Jew who followed Stalin's tune after the nonaggression pact with Hitler was not an idealist but an arrogant brainwashed stooge of Stalin. The sainted Pete Seeger was such an arrogant lefty he was very late in admitting that perhaps Stalin was more than a hard driver. The NY Times reported the folk singer criticized the Soviet dictator “at least as early” as 1993, only 40 years after Stalin’s death!

I recall Alger Hiss, after he got out of prison, with a placard proclaiming his innocence and handing out petitions in front of the Federal Court House. Of course when the files of the NKVD were opened after the fall of the Soviet Union it turns out he was guilty as hell.

You just don't know what you are talking about when it came to American communists of the Rosenberg's generation.

I was born in 1957, but this case has saddened me all my life. I've studied the histories, and followed the various Greenglass/Rosenberg/Meeropol developments since I was in my early teens. Of course, the "secrets" the convicted conspirators passed along were too vague to have been of any practical use to the Soviets, which makes their treasonously naïve idealism all the more senseless. The Soviet Union (especially under Stalin, who ruled until his death a few months before the Rosenbergs were executed) was never actually "Communist" any more than the Nazis were national "socialists" or Mao's China was a "People's Republic" -- they were all totalitarian regimes ruled by dictators. But Khrushchev didn't expose Stalin's massive atrocities (on a scale comparable to Hitler's and Mao's) until 1956. I wonder how the Rosenbergs would have reacted. I like to think it would have crushed them, because I don't believe they were "bad people" despite what they did.

You are totally off base. It was definitely not a kangaroo court (although they may have liked a Stalin based one since that was who they were serving). As for "Nazi-style", your idea is both offensive and insensitive to those who actually suffered under the Nazis.

I catch him when he's sober, teach him how to walk that line,

Man turns his back on his family, he ain't no friend of mine.

He never said ... Ethel did not type the documents -- and I lied and said she did. He said that either his Wife or Ethel typed the documents -- and he agreed to support his wife when she said she did not type them. The lie was saying he was sure Ethel typed the documents.

One of them did .. and other information had already implicated Ethel. This was not the only charge.

The greater question always has been -- should she have been excited .. not was she guilty.
They committed treason, but the value of what they gave the Soviet Union was nil.
No, please read the article, all the way to the end.  Oil is what Bush was going after, not weapons that were manufactured in the 1990s.

...of course WMD's were "there" all along-which bush-cheney knew, as they knew
WE gave them, and intel where-when to fire them against Iranians....Saddam and troops were U.S. proxy...Rumsfeld is on video shaking hands with Saddam over deal....as stated often after invasion, these weapons were so out of date they were unusable.....except as bush-cheney warmonger propaganda....

johnnyH, as we seeded the you and him fight between Iraq and Iran we gave so called "Weapons of mass destruction" to Iraq that also were used against the Kurds with our Bush blessings.  Give up ignorance and see the light.
Yes, and they pre-dated 1991, They were from the era of the Iraq-Iran War and now useless for anything. This is clearly stated in the article.
Wow...so weapons of mass destruction were there all along?  Whodathunkit.  I'd say that liberal credibility takes another hit, but liberals don't have any credibility.
I have said this on these boards many times and been shouted down.
Well, since it was his pentagon which did the cover up, I guess I would have to ask, what did they know and when did they know it?  Another "leftist" question.
The old chemical weapons either count, or they don't. If we can't put them on the table for Bush, we certainly can't put them on the table 10 years later for ISIL.
The story got out to you, didn't it?  Isn't that transparency?

Is there any excuse for President Obama's concealment of this from the public for six years now?  To all those commenters who blindly defend our President:  blame this exclusively on Bush all you want, but where is Obama's vaunted "transparency" now?

Ask your friend George Bush to define "weapons of mass destruction."  I guess they are only weapons of mass destruction if they are produced by Iraq - otherwise they are just silly little bits leftover weaponry, made by the USA.
I agree and I wonder whether we can expect follow up investigative reports on the spin machine that is no doubt running overtime as we speak.
The idiocy has already begun. Just read some of these comments.
This story will be misunderstood and misquoted for months to come, you can be sure.

It does not seem right that the military and the government government were less than truthful about the chemical weapons discovered in Iraq and that they hid this truth for so long. What kind of example does that set for citizens and corporations? How does this affect our trust in the statements and policies of our government? In light of these revelations about the veracity of our military and it's chemical weapons programs, what might the government be trying to suppress about its bio-weapon program? It is shocking to me that the Army began experimenting with the Ebola virus over 30 years ago and yet we still do not have an approved vaccine or cure, much less a stockpile of such drugs available in case of an emergency. Who bears responsibility for these government oversights?

Iraq did not have the WMDs Bush said they had, the WMDs that would have perhaps justified the invasion.  Iraq had old unusable WMDs that we helped him make to fight Iran.  And our armed forces covered it up.

comments.userLocation: Lewis Family Farm, Essex, New York
comments.commentBody: What are the implications when our government lies as a matter of course? How can a democracy work when the military becomes a law unto itself? Who manufactured the nerve agents and chemicals and profiteered only to have the department of Defense lie to protect them over the years? How do we respect our Defense department when it systematically trashes troops injured in a war zone to hide criminals and chemicals discovered that will embarrass our own in war? Secret casualties has open a can sealer ages ago: Bravo many times!!!

"Isis" is not a "splinter group"-it's competence is based upon Saddam's Baathist military and generals, whom Bush-Cheney-Bremer shunted aside, refusing to utilize......and in the end, PAID U.S. taxpayer $$$$ to, to NOT fight our troops...
(while kicking that can down road to next U.S. president...)

Do you think ISIS really has more know-how as to how to handle these things than our troops did?  Giving ISIS this whole territory to roam through is probably going to decimate their ranks faster than anything else.  What do you think is going to happen to them when they start picking up these munitions and handling them?  Do you think ISIS is going to have better care units than our troops had?

A chemical shell could still be ~usable in an ad-hoc fashion, while being in such a poor condition that no regular military would choose to do so.

If, for instance, an artillery shell is aging and has been stored in poor conditions, with noxious chemicals inside, and it's now corroded and leaking -- most armies would rather seal and/or destroy the round rather than risk firing it. Firing it in an artillery piece would be gambling on many things, like the round properly clearing the barrel sufficiently intact to be dangerous somewhere else instead of contaminating everything around you.

However, ISIS may not be *that* fastidious. Some of their attacks on military bases have been preceded by suicidal attackers in car bombs to breach outer defenses so the following attackers have a way in. One could imagine somebody who sought martyrdom in the name of jihad being honored at the thought of attempting to deliver a headline-grabbing sarin-filled shell - leaking or otherwise -- with a jury-rigged detonator into a targeted area.

"These encounters carry worrisome implications now that the Islamic State, a Qaeda splinter group, controls much of the territory where the weapons were found."

The article insists several times that Bush was not seeking these weapons but then goes on to say the above. If they can be used by ISIS, then they are in fact active weapons. The distinction between active program and active weapons is not real to victims.

Regardless, good work NYT. I feel for our soldiers.
Funny how the left pus so much emphasis on "sovereignty" when it refers to a criminal tyrant's domain, but laughs off the idea when it comes to protecting U.S. territory from the wandering masses.

What a disgusting indictment of the Bush Administration and the U.S. Defense Department. Congratulations to the new York Times for investigating and reporting this very sad story.

Now what will the Obama Administration do for these veterans: probably nothing. Will the Defense Department investigate and assist the injured veterans: probably not.
Wow! Imagine that. Our country lying to us again!

Just as Bachmann is leaving center stage, and  we were rid of her rabid 'scientific' theories,  this candidate from Iowa pops up. Unbelievable that Ernst is leading in the polls - what are Iowans thinking?

Hm.  It seems grossly irresponsible to not clearly mark ordnance types where there might be confusion and terrible consequences resulting.  Isn't it common practice for most armies to clearly mark such things as training rounds, HE, HEAT so that they can be easily distinguished and improper selection averted?

Bush is a liar? Well then what about Bill Clinton and Nancy Pelosi:

"One way or the other, we are determined to deny Iraq the capacity to develop weapons of mass destruction and the missiles to deliver them. That is our bottom line." --President Bill Clinton, Feb. 4, 1998

"If Saddam rejects peace and we have to use force, our purpose is clear. We want to seriously diminish the threat posed by Iraq's weapons of mass destruction program." --President Bill Clinton, Feb. 17, 1998

"Saddam Hussein has been engaged in the development of weapons of mass destruction technology which is a threat to countries in the region and he has made a mockery of the weapons inspection process." -Rep. Nancy Pelosi (D, CA), Dec. 16, 1998

Derek Thompson's The Atlantic article on why poor people make bad decisions remains timely and excellent in this sort of discussion. The logic and logistics of living on various levels of limited incomes differs from living on an albeit tight middle class income. The decision-making becomes radically different as you move along the income ladder.

"It was widely seen as a counter-argument to claims that poor people are “to blame” for bad decisions and a rebuke to policies that withhold money from the poorest families unless they behave in a certain way. After all, if being poor leads to bad decision-making (as opposed to the other way around), then giving cash should alleviate the cognitive burdens of poverty, all on its own."

http://www.rimaregas.com/2014/07/your-brain-on-poverty-why-poor-people-s...
